abstract: Records reveal that lifting of deed restrictions by New York City agency on use of Lower East Side nursing home Rivington House, which paved way for building to be sold for luxury housing development, was result of city mismanagement; records also show agency had been paid over $16 million by building owner to do so, contradicting Mayor Bill de Blasio's statement that his administration, which has sought to limit luxury housing, was blindsided by developments.
lead_paragraph: The Rivington House deal, netting by far the largest sum received by the city for a deed change during the de Blasio administration, went largely unnoticed, despite community efforts to retain the building as a long-term care center.

headline.main: How New York Allowed Gentrification for $16 Million
headline.print_headline: Nursing Home’s Sale to Condo Developer Raises Questions for City

snippet: The Rivington House deal, netting by far the largest sum received by the city for a deed change during the de Blasio administration, went largely unnoticed, despite community efforts to retain the building as a long-term care center.
